qas.question: What has Guam recently being trying to protect?
What has led to the decrease of fish near Guam?
What is the name of the flying mammal in Guam that some are concerned for?
Who made Tumon Bay into a preserve?
What is the #1 cause of decreased fish populations?
The Guam National Wildlife Refuge is near which tourist area?
What most endangered the Mariana fruit bats?
What most endangered the sea turtle population?

context: Efforts have been made to protect Guam's <a0_0>coral reef habitats<a0_0/> from <a1_0><b6_0>pollution<b6_0/>, <b7_0>eroded silt<b7_0/> and <b4_0>overfishing<b4_0/><a1_0/>, problems that have led to decreased fish populations. (Since Guam is a significant vacation spot for scuba divers, this is important.) In recent years, the Department of Agriculture, Division of Aquatic and Wildlife Resources has established several new marine preserves where fish populations are monitored by biologists. Before adopting U.S. Environmental Protection Agency standards, portions of <b5_0>Tumon Bay<b5_0/> were dredged by the <b3_0>hotel chains<b3_0/> to provide a better experience for hotel guests. Tumon Bay has since been made into a preserve. A federal Guam National Wildlife Refuge in northern Guam protects the decimated sea turtle population in addition to a small colony of <a2_0>Mariana fruit bats<a2_0/>.
